facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 472 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 472 of 1962. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 23, 1960,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated December 23, 1960 of Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 464 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 23, 1960, of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 464 of 1958. K. Garg, S.C. Agarwala, D.P. Singh and M.K. Ramamurthi, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appellant appointed on June 11, 1949 as officiating Assistant Director Grade II in office of Textile Commissioner, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was in the service of the Union of India. He was appointed on June 11, 1949 as an officiating Assistant Director Grade II in the office of the Textile, Commissioner, Bombay and was working as such till September 15, 1954.

facts.text: Appointment was temporary and services liable to termination on one month's notice on either side.

anchor.surface_text: The appointment was temporary and his services were liable to be terminated on one months numberice on either side. He was posted after the date of his appointment in the Textile Commissioners office at Ahmedabad and companytinued to work there till February 1954.

facts.text: Appellant posted to Textile Commissioner's office at Ahmedabad after appointment and continued till February 1954.

anchor.surface_text: He was posted after the date of his appointment in the Textile Commissioners office at Ahmedabad and companytinued to work there till February 1954. He was transferred to Bombay in February 1954 and was informed in August 1954 that his services would be terminated from September 15, 1954.

facts.text: Appellant transferred to Bombay in February 1954.

anchor.surface_text: He was transferred to Bombay in February 1954 and was informed in August 1954 that his services would be terminated from September 15, 1954. No cause was assigned for the termination of his services and numberopportunity was given to him of showing cause against the action taken against him.

facts.text: Services terminated from September 15, 1954, informed in August 1954.

anchor.surface_text: No cause was assigned for the termination of his services and numberopportunity was given to him of showing cause against the action taken against him. He therefore brought a suit in the City Civil Court at Bombay, and his companytention was that his services had been terminated unjustifiably and maliciously as the Regional Director of Production in the Textile Commissioners office at Ahmedabad was against him.

facts.text: No cause assigned for termination and no opportunity given to show cause.

anchor.surface_text: He therefore brought a suit in the City Civil Court at Bombay, and his companytention was that his services had been terminated unjustifiably and maliciously as the Regional Director of Production in the Textile Commissioners office at Ahmedabad was against him.

facts.text: On December 29, 1953, appellant called upon to explain irregularities and state why disciplinary action should not be taken.

anchor.surface_text: Because of this on December 29, 1953, the appellant was called upon to explain certain irregularities and was also asked to submit his explanation and to state why disciplinary action should number be taken against him. The appellant went on to state in the plaint that certain enquiries were held against him behind his back but the matter was number pursued and he was transferred to Bombay in February 1954.

facts.text: Certain enquiries held against appellant behind his back after Dec 29, 1953 memo, but not pursued.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant went on to state in the plaint that certain enquiries were held against him behind his back but the matter was number pursued and he was transferred to Bombay in February 1954. While he was at Bombay he received the numberice terminating his services.

facts.text: Appellant claimed quasi-permanent employee under Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: He claimed that he was a quasi- permanent employee under the Central Civil Services  Temporary Service  Rules, 1949,  hereinafter referred to as the Rules  and numberaction under r. 5 of the Rules companyld be taken against him.

facts.text: Appellant entitled to protection of Art. 311, termination without complying bad.

anchor.surface_text: He was further entitled to the protection of Art. 311 of the Constitution and as his services were terminated without companyplying with that provision the order was bad and liable to be set aside.

facts.text: Order of termination dated August 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant therefore prayed that the order of August 13, 1954 by which his services were terminated be declared illegal and inoperative and he be declared a quasi permanent employee and reinstated in service.

facts.text: Union of India defended that appellant not quasi-permanent, r.5 applied, valid, no discrimination.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was opposed by the Union of India and its main defence was that the appellant was number a quasi permanent employee and that r. 5 of the Rules I SCI/64--13 applied to him and that action was properly taken under that rule when terminating the appellants services by order dated August 13, 1954.

facts.text: Admitted that memo dated December 29, 1953 issued to appellant, directed to submit explanation to Under Secretary, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: It was admitted that the memo. dated December 29, 1953 was issued to the appellant and he was directed to submit his explanation in respect of the irregularities mentioned therein to the Under Secretary, Government of India, New Delhi and to state why disciplinary action should number be taken against him.

facts.text: Admitted departmental inquiry conducted from December 1953, but not pursued as evidence not conclusive.

anchor.surface_text: It was also admitted that from December 1953 onwards some department inquiry was companyducted against the appellant but it was averted that the said departmental inquiry was number pursued as the evidence against him was number companysidered to be companyclusive.

facts.text: Appellant transferred to Bombay in February 1954 to give chance of improvement as work not satisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: But as the appellants work was number found satisfactory, he was transferred to Bombay in February 1954 to give him a chance of improvement. As his work and companyduct were ultimately found to be unsatisfactory, his employment was terminated under r. 5 of the Rules as he was a temporary employee.

facts.text: Trial court held against appellant on all points, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held on all these points against the appellant and dismissed the stilt. The appellant then went in appeal to the High Court.

facts.text: Bombay High Court agreed with trial court, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the trial companyrt and dismissed the appeal. The appellant then applied for a certificate to appeal to this Court, which was granted and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Appellant in continuous government service for more than three years by 1954, but no declaration under r.3(ii).

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that though the appellant had been in service for more than three years by 1954, numberdeclaration as required by sub-cl.  ii  of r. 3 has ever been made in his case.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellant not quasi-permanent employee.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that fails for companysideration is whether the appellant was a quasi permanent employee and r. 5 did number apply to him. ... He cannot therefore claim to be in quasi-permanent service.

facts.text: r.5 valid, not hit by Art.16, no discrimination.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that companysidering the nature of the employment of a temporary government servant, a provision like that in r. 5 in respect of termination of service is a. reasonable provision which cannot be said to deny equality of opportunity provided in Art. 16.

facts.text: Termination not by way of punishment, no protection under Art.311(2).

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that on the facts of this case Art. 311 2  has numberapplication and the appellant was number entitled to the protection of that Article before his services were terminated under r. 5,

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 of the Rules, which falls for consideration in this connection, is as follows A Government servant shall be deemed to be in quasi-permanent service-- if he has been in continuous Government service for more than three years if the appointing authority, being satisfied as to his suitability in respect of age, qualifications, work and character, for employment in a quasi permanent capacity has issued a declaration to that effect, in accordance with such instructions as the Governor-General may issue from time to time.

concepts.interpretation: Two sub-clauses to be read conjunctively; both continuous service >3 years AND declaration of suitability required to deem quasi-permanent.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: declaration quasi-permanent service cannot begin. If therefore the appellants companytention were to be accepted and a temporary government servant c

anchor.surface_text: under the Central Civil Services Temporary Service Rules, 1949, hereinafter referred to as the Rules and no action under r. 5 of the Rules could be taken against him. He was further entitled to the protection of Art. 311 of the Constitution

concepts.interpretation: Allows termination of temporary govt servant's service by 1 month's notice or pay in lieu; valid and applied here as appellant was temporary.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: nd this Court laid down five propositions therein. It is the third proposition therein on which strong reliance has been placed on behalf of the appel

anchor.surface_text: reading these two rules together the conclusion is inevitable that we must read the two sub-clauses conjunctively and hold that both conditions must be fulfilled before a Government servant can be deemed to be in quasi-permanent service

concepts.interpretation: Rule 3 read in harmony with definition in Rule 2(b); disjunctive reading would create irreconcilability.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to formal departmental enquiry where punishment contemplated; includes right to cross-examine, lead evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Quasi-permanent service is defined in r. 2 (b) as meaning temporary service commencing from the date on which a declaration issued under r. 3 takes effect and consists of periods of duty and leave (other than extraordinary leave) after that date.

concepts.interpretation: Commences only upon declaration under r.3; requires both conditions of r.3.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: e quasi-permanent be entitled to the same companyditions of service in respect of leave, allowances and disciplinary matters as a government servant i

anchor.surface_text: The classification of government servants into these classes is reasonable and differences in the matter of termination of service between these classes cannot be said to be discriminatory in the circumstances.

concepts.interpretation: Classification of temporary vs quasi-permanent vs permanent govt servants reasonable for different termination rules; no violation of Art.16.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ntal enquiry was going to be held particularly when the charges were given by the Settlement Officer who had apparently been appointed the enquiry off

anchor.surface_text: temporary servants are also entitled to the protection of Art. 311 (2) in the same manner as permanent government servants, if the government takes action against them by meting out one of the three punishments

concepts.interpretation: Available only if termination by way of punishment (dismissal, removal, reduction); not for simple termination under r.5.
Termination not punishment unless (1) no right to post or (2) evil consequences/stigma; motive irrelevant if under contract/rule.

trial court and High Court held against appellant on all points

anchor.surface_text: The trial court held on all these points against the appellant and dismissed the suit. The appellant then went in appeal to the High Court. The High Court agreed with the trial court

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees and dismisses appeal

holdings.text: The two sub-clauses of Rule 3 of the Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949 must be read conjunctively and both conditions must be fulfilled before a Government servant can be deemed to be in quasi-permanent service.

anchor.surface_text: reading these two rules together the conclusion is inevitable that we must read the two sub-clauses conjunctively and hold that both conditions must be fulfilled before a Government servant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Rule 2(b) defining quasi-permanent service (commences on declaration under Rule 3) with Rule 3 requires conjunctive reading; disjunctive reading creates irreconcilability; scheme of Rules 4-10 confirms declaration necessary.

holdings.text: The appellant cannot claim to be in quasi-permanent service as no declaration under sub-clause (ii) of Rule 3 was issued despite more than three years of continuous service.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that though the appellant had been in service for more than three years by 1954, no declaration as required by sub-cl. ii of r. 3 has ever been made in his case. He cannot therefore claim to be in quasi-permanent service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts undisputed: continuous service >3 years but no declaration of suitability by appointing authority as required conjunctively under Rule 3.

holdings.text: Rule 5 of the Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949 is valid and not hit by Article 16 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that considering the nature of the employment of a temporary government servant, a provision like that in r. 5 in respect of termination of service is a reasonable provision which cannot be said to deny equality of opportunity provided in Art. 16.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification of government servants into permanent, quasi-permanent, and temporary is reasonable given nature of temporary employment; different termination rules do not deny equality of opportunity.

holdings.text: The termination of the appellant's services was not discriminatory and does not violate Article 16.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Termination due to unsatisfactory work/conduct, not retrenchment by abolition of post; no requirement to terminate all similarly situated employees; retention of juniors irrelevant.

holdings.text: The appellant, a temporary government servant, was not entitled to protection under Article 311(2) as termination under Rule 5 was not by way of punishment.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that on the facts of this case Art. 311 2 has no application and the appellant was not entitled to the protection of that Article before his services were terminated under r. 5

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Dhingra tests: no right to post under temporary appointment; no evil consequences/stigma in termination order; preliminary inquiry dropped, no formal departmental inquiry held; motive irrelevant.

holdings.text: A preliminary inquiry is distinct from a formal departmental inquiry and is not governed by Article 311(2) or principles of natural justice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Preliminary inquiry for government's satisfaction to decide on punishment vs simple termination under rules; formal inquiry follows if punishment intended, with full natural justice protections.

holdings.text: No formal departmental inquiry was held against the appellant after the December 29, 1953 memorandum, and termination was under Rule 5 for unsatisfactory work.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Memorandum called for explanation but no charges framed, no inquiry officer, no evidence led/cross-examined; inquiry dropped, appellant transferred, terminated later after observing work in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Madan Gopal v. The State of Punjab 3 . In that case Madan Gopal was a temporary government servant. He was also asked to explain why disciplinary action should number be taken against him.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bihar v. Gopi Kishore Prasad 1 . That was a case of a probationer and this Court laid down five propositions therein. It is the third proposition therein on which strong reliance has been placed on behalf of the appellant.
